title: Ticket #7660: Python ExprTrees should be able to parenthesize themselves
description:
classad.ExprTree should have a method that returns the same expression, but wrapped in parentheses. This would be helpful when building up complex expressions.

In particular, the fact that these give the same result is a problem: 

>>> x = classad.ExprTree("x == 1")
>>> y = classad.ExprTree("y == 2")
>>> z = classad.ExprTree("z == 3")
>>> (x & y) | z
x == 1 & y == 2 | z == 3
>>> x & (y | z)
x == 1 & y == 2 | z == 3

We can't fix that, but we can do (x & y).parenthesize() | z.

I don't have any strong opinions on the name of the method. parenthesize is accurate but long and hard to type. Maybe wrap or group?
remarks:
2020-May-22 10:40:00 by tlmiller:
I think the actual problem is with the operators used here. Python will evaluate (x & y) | z in the correct order -- calling __and__ followed by __or__. Both functions need to parenthesize their arguments: 

x & y -> (x) & (y)
w | z -> (w) | (z)
------------------
(x & y) | z -> ((x) & (y)) | (z)

An obvious optimization would be to not parenthesize 'simple' ExprTrees.

2020-May-22 10:50:44 by tlmiller:
Actually, thinking about the C++ implementation, I realized it would be harder to implement this wrong behavior than the correct one. So I tried: 

>>> w = (x & y) | z
>>> w.eval()
10
>>> q = x & (y | z)
>>> q.eval()
2

which sure makes it look like the issue is just one of converting ExprTrees to strings. (Either we don't parenthesize subexpressions, or we do but have a bug in optimizing the extra ones away.)
